subject: Re: [junit] Newbie question about the best practice for organizing 	and running tests
msgSnippet: I find it helpful to put unit tests in their own directory but in a *different* package from the code under test so that they must test through the object s
messageBody:
I find it helpful to put unit tests in their own directory but in a
*different* package from the code under test so that they must test
through the object's public API and cannot cheat by using members with
package-scope visibility. I find it gives me quicker feedback on API
design issues.

I'll name the test packages after the system packages, usually by
adding ".test" on the end. E.g.

project/src/package1
project/src/package2
project/unit-tests/package1/tests
project/unit-tests/package2/tests

--Nat


2009/3/25 Colin Vipurs <zodiaczx6@...>:
> David,
>
> One of the easiest ways I've found of doing this is to put your test classes
> into a seperate directory which is solely for tests and mirrors the package
> structure of your production classes, so you might end up with something
> like:
>
> project/
> src/
> package1/
> package2/
> test/
> package1/
> package2/
>
> You should be able to just select the test directory as the root of your
> test launcher, be it your IDE or ant or whatever.
>
